I remember back in the day when my friend's bands would play Kimo's, we'd always come by beforehand to indulge in some fish and chips made by the Korean family that still owns it to this day. I must say that during these downtrodden days of the failing economy, even the size of the fish at this joint has been affected. Regardless, the place still has some primo grub. 

I had a 2 piece fish and chips and a side of 'shroomage. It was, as we say in Tagalog, PANALO! (For you non-speakers, it means WINNER!)
author: Ivan F.

description:
Two pieces of fish with a bunch of fries for $6.40, made on the spot, so you have to wait. Place is totally stark, with bright fluorescent lights and very minimal decors (not white leather couch minimalist decor, but as in nothing but a couple of chairs and a bottle of malt vinegar on the table minimal decor.) 

The Korean couple that runs the place looks like genuine nice people who don't forget to chat and joke with each other while working the frier. 

Fries plus ketchup plus malt vinegar brings this unbelievable great flavor. Fish pieces are not bad either. 

The fact that the light is so bright makes you feel a little tired and dazed, which is kinda perfect if you want to reminisce about your drunken youth and the blurry days in London.
author: Candice B.

description:
I ate here three times last week and you won't hear me complain about a thing. 

Now of course this place is not located in the heart of London were all you fish and chip aficionados have had what you consider the best. Yea, yea..Been there, done that. I do think the best F&C you can find in balmy old London is out in South Reslip. 

Picadilly's does a good job and you won't be disappointed. 

Give it a try after quaffing about a gallon of ale across the street.
author: Wayne B.

description:
Hard work out + 3 Gin and Tonics = Feeling good and slightly mellow

Feeling nice and slightly mellow + Fish and Chips  drowned in vinegar + sweet and friendly owners = Big smiles, happy and all right with the world

Nothing wrong with either of those equations!
author: Jenn A.

description:
One of your friends had a near death experience, and he tells the goddamn story all the time. At bars and lounges he captivates his audience with his harrowing tale of overcoming death, and how he now sees life in a different, more beautiful light. Men call him an inspiration and women give him their phone numbers.This usually leaves you sitting alone in the corner because everyone constantly gathers around him, and really, who wants to hang out with someone who hasn't had a near death experience?

"Never again!" you shout as you barge through the door of Piccadilly Fish and Chips. Todays the day you decide to change all that. Yep, that's right, today's the day you start on a mission to give yourself a heart attack. "As soon as I survive that", you think to yourself, "I'll have my own goddamn near death story, and all the fame and fortune I deserve!"

Slap a $20 down on the counter and say "I want all the fish and chips you can give me!"

In about three minutes, you'll have an nine piece fish and chip plate handed to you. Don't forget to ask for the tartar sauce, because they keep it in a pitcher behind the counter. Point to the spot on your plate that you want the tartar, and the lady behind the counter will slop it on. Tell the lady "More" five times. That should give you the proper amount of tartar.

The fish, although fresh and crispy, will be lacking a bit on the flavor side. You'll ponder that for a moment, then realize that you got a lot of goddamn fish to eat. Even though you'll be stuffed by the fifth fish, don't give up. If there's one thing you've learned from watching all those Will Smith movies, it's to never give up. The fish will be so greasy that you won't even have to chew that last four pieces, and you can just let them slide down your throat.

Go here for lunch and get the nine piece fish and chips until you have a heart attack. It should take about three weeks. When it happens, it's gonna hurt. Oh it's gonna hurt like hell. The pain, however terrible, pales in comparison to the knowledge that for the rest of your life you'll be able tell one kick ass story about the time you almost died. A smile will creep across your face as you use the last of your strength and dial 911. Now fight to live goddammit, fight!
author: Dave G.

description:
When it comes to making me happy I am not an overly complicated person. It really doesn't take much to get me in good spirits. I like simple things, like a carefully brewed cup of coffee, pumpkin ice cream from Mitchell's, fish and chips.....

MMMM......Fish and Chips, I don't always crave it but when I do, I hit up Picadilly's on Polk. Yeah the food is greasy but come on-it's fish and chips. It's deep fried and golden and crispy good. Although they have other seafood and veggie options, all deep-fried of course, I go with the standard 3 piece with fries. Some fish with malt vinegar and beer, sometimes that is all I need. Like I said it's easy get an ear to ear grin out of me.
author: X marks the spot ..

description:
Dry your eyes mates Picadilly is OPEN. After being closed for several months due to fire (I'm thinking grease fire, just a wild guess) they've opened their doors again sporting new floors, fresh paint and hell, I think they even changed the oil in the fryer.

I don't eat much fish 'n chips because while I like the idea of it, I KNOW that I'm going to feel like shit immediately afterward. I'd like to say that this place is different but, no, I still feel like shit. That's alright though because sometimes you've just got to satisfy a grease craving.
author: Josua P.

description:
While the fish portion is superior to the chips portion, I have to say I enjoyed my meal overall.  The fact that the fish is hand-dipped upon ordering adds to the experience. Although the setting is nothing to write home about with clean but plain counter service, the family that runs it is very friendly and will not cut corners. A small piece of fish? You'll probably end up with two of them to make up for the inadequate size and to ensure you are properly full.

Hrm...now why is it that the above statement sounds a little X-rated?
author: Audrey J.

description:
It isn't the best, but then again, exactly who or what can you compare it to. It's not like there's fish n chips places all over SF - unlike tacquerias. Actually, at one time (when I was a kid), there were quite a few of them in the Richmond and Sunset. But that was in the early 80's when I was in highschool. (Yup, local guy here).

I have to say, when I do crave it - and I mean I have to really crave it, I go here. Liverpool Lil's has great fish n chip, but that place is more of a sit down place and if I remember right, it's 15 bucks. That's not right.
author: Ted P.

description:
There are only a handful of Fish & Chips places here in SF that I'm aware of and Piccadilly Fish & Chips was one of those places that I passed by many times but didn't dare go in not knowing whether I'll get sick eating there or not. 

Glad to announce that I finally ate there and am alive and well. My tummy was very happy after having their 2 piece Fish & Chips with a side order of fried clams. The fish was really light and perfectly battered...went great with the carefully-monitored tartar sauce that they'd reluctantly give you when asked. Though I find the chips were not crispy as I'd like them. Despite that, I have been back a couple of times and kept ordering the same 2-piece fish and chips and forgot to try their onion rings. I'll definitely have to try their 2-piece fish with onion rings next time! 

Great people working hard behind the counter. It's a nice hole in the wall to either dine in with eclectic folks or take it to go...great either way.
author: Jen L.

description:
I woke up on my floor.  Confused.  I had no clue what time it was or how long I had been out.

Before I moved I looked at my surroundings: nothing unfamiliar.  I think I left the television on.  And some grease-stained newspaper strewn about my table.

A mayonnaisy substance on my fingers and face.  

I got up and poured a glass of water in hopes it would do something about my headache and lingering nausea.  

As I sat in a haze, memories started coming; only pieces.

A white room.  A deep fryer the size of my car.  A chinese woman.

I don't remem-  Oh....  Oh God...   Oh NO!    

I've been Brain-Raped by Fish & Chips again!!
author: Patrick A.

description:
I may not know too much about the fish, because I don't do the surf much.  But I did try the chicken, chips, onion rings and the mushrooms.

I think that everything, except the chips are fried in the same oil, and who knows when it was changed last.  They all might have the same coating too.  Everything is coated heavy in salt.

Several kinds of fish are available, from scallops to crab, to squid.  Prices range from about $7 for two pieces of fish with chips or onion rings to $11 for 5 or 6 pieces with chips.  

I think this place is much cleaner than the last time I was here.  Your To-Go container is newspaper, and by the time you get to where you are going, you'll be lucky the oil has not soaked through.  All in all, some of the best fries I've had, but over salted.
author: Michael M.

description:
Not sure how I'm supposed to feel about this place.

I stumbled in last night after the Elite event across the street at O'reilly's Holy Grail. I needed something to bond with the Guiness in my innards. Fish and chips seemed the logical choice in every way

You wouldn't necessarily expect a couple of middle aged Asian ladies to be frying up fish and chips around midnight on a Wednesday, but this being San Francisco, you wouldn't necessarily not expect it either.

The fish was good, chips could have used a little more frying.
author: Jason R.

description:
Just like the chippy back home, innit.

They need to learn how to fry up some Mars bars.

Pip pip.
author: Adrian L.

description:
Somehow the sign caught my attention and got me craving for some fish and chips, which is rare because I'm not a fish and chip person.  Actually, I'm not much into fried food except fried chicken.  

Anyway, I think this place has been here a long time.  Hubby said it used to be H&S way back when, I recall a H&S on Polk but I thought it was closer toward Sacramento/Clay.  The place is bigger than I expected or remembered, specifically the seating to the side.  Seeing the two Korean ladies was also a surprise.  The older one manned the fryer and the younger one was the cashier.  

We got the 2 piece with onion rings for under $7.  I was tempted to try the 9 pieces of squid for $2.75.  It took a while because they fried to order.  Hubby said the younger woman insisted on putting the vinegar and salt for him even though he asked a few times to do it himself.  I told him that's called service.
 
It was piping hot, burning hot!  The fish was flaky but after a few bites, it was already too much fried food (oil) for me.  I didn't care for the batter on the onion rings - it was a bit lumpy and soft - but the onion itself was sweet.  We didn't know about the tartar sauce, it may have been better with it...actually, I would have loved some BBQ sauce.  I know, I'm a bit strange but I love BBQ sauce on all fried food.
author: Gloria H.

description:
ahhh salt and vinegar on mine any day..........

Don't know why, but we keep missing this place when we try to find it, but now we have, I am coming back. The Korean ladies behind the counter were sweet- after a few gestures exchanged, we figured we could help ourselves to seats and the drinks fridge while we waited for our 2 portions of fish and chips.

Why is it so hard to find whole fillets of battered deep fried fish in the Bay Area? I have been hunting high and low near the british pubs for a slice of battered goodness to be disapointed by some fish steak  sitting in grease. I have to say though, despite the fish fillets were small, I was a very satisfied person when I left this place. The food was fried to order so it was hot, crispy, and not greasy   It felt like a chippy from back home (it had a proper fryer unit), all we needed here were 'pukka' pies, gherkins and saveloys.... hmmmm... 

other things on the menu were fried chicken, onion rings, fried prawns, scallops and oysters. One day I am going starve myself and have the $9.90 special- one pc fish, 2 shrimp and 3 oysters with chips...... (or was it onion rings with that?) heck ,all this with a great range of sodas to wash it all down....

be careful- the only food not fried is the colesaw (lots of mayo, but freshly homemade), so dont come here if you trying to lose weight!
author: Sushi Y.

description:
This place is only two blocks away from my place so I'll come here whenever I find myself getting trashed on polk street. 

Let's be clear about one thing. This isn't a place to go for fine dining. It's sort of like Chinatown meets dive bar that serves fish and chips. 

Now that we have that out of the way, I can tell you that the fish here is super good. The frying job on these things are perfect. Crispy on the outside and the fish inside is cooked well enough to where it's still moist.
author: Trung V.

description:
Yeah.....fish and chips.. Fish and chips....fries.....no.....they're called chips dummy. This is the spot. Oh hell yeah...just thinking about that deep fried goodness, smothered in ketchup and tartar, makes me wanna run naked through the Tenderloin, which I wouldn't recommend. 
I did ask the little old asian lady how old the deep frier is in that joint. Anybody wanna guess? Longer than most of you yelpers and your fams have spent on the West Coast. The reason those fish and chips taste so damn good is because that frier is over 80 years old....boo yow!!!
author: Sam S.

description:
Yeah .... they are open again....

Bambi recommends the 3 piece with chips and extra vinegar...
author: Teddy d.

description: Food was greasy and bland. Looked good but tasted so so. Cash only here.
author: Dan W.

description:
Here's an analogy:

malt vinegar stench : deep-fried anything guy 
                            :: 
cigarette smoke : smoker

Yeah, they smell sickly-sweet, a little bit caustic, and you know they're going to affect you adversely, but they also make you want to damage your health with them. 

Piccadilly Fish & Chips stinks from half a block away, in exactly that way.  Peek inside and it you'll notice that it looks like the kind of place where you shouldn't be -- spotty fluorescent lights, splochy wallpaper, a general sense that it could use some electrical work (not to mention a cleaning).  

But fried food tastes great, and they do a decent job of it.  

This is not a sober food.
author: Phil K.

description:
They had some GIGANTIC fryolators at this place.  The "chef" at my fraternity house would have been proud!

The fried oysters were fry-o-licious and the fried imitation crab was also fry-tastic.  I mean seriously, who needs their imitation crab with healthy ingredients like seaweed, rice cucumber and avacado?

The restaurant is really ugly inside, but I couldn't say I cared much at half-past-drunk-o'clock.
author: Rocco B.

description:
Baccarat taste with a Dixie cup budget?  Fear not, weary diner.  This joint has risen from the ashes (closed by a fire for a while) to again regale you with flaky white fish battered to perfection.  Maybe they were able to save some of their magic oil from the flames.  Everything tastes the same as before.  The original patina'd interior of course is gone (fresh paint will do that), but you'll still leave feeling like a greasy Gorton's fisherman, and the wee bit of malt vinegar clinging to your lips on the way home reminds you that all is good in the universe.

Would give if 5 stars if they improved the lighting - damn folks, if the space shuttle can see your fish fry from Mars, then it's time to dim the damn lights.  It's not as if deep-frying requires it, and besides - everyone looks just a little bit better when not being bathed in 728 fluorescents.
author: Mc Matty b.

description:
Ok, there are not too many places we won't go back to when there are fries and grease on the menu. This however is an exception. 

We decided to have a bit of a variety and try the fish and chips and the clams and onion rings. I have never had anything this greasy, Ok, maybe once but this definitely ranks up there. A full quart of 10W30 in every piece of fish. Amazing. There must have been an issue with the temperature of the fat .... it just got soaked into the food.

The fish was greasy and tasteless, the fries were not fully cooked, there was a minimum amount of clams but ... yes there is a but ... the onion rings were not bad at all. So, if all you want is a side of onion rings give the place a chance. If you want more ... keep on walking!
author: The A.

description:
Things we got:

Fish: Very Good
Chips: Good
Chicken: Awful

So on fish alone, I would have given this place 4 stars.  If you factor in the chicken, and the place itself, 3 stars is maybe pushing it.  I really liked the crispiness of the fish with the malt vinegar and tartar sauce.  I thought the flavors were all very good.  As for the chicken...let's just say it was horrible.  The pieces were small and extremely overcooked.  The chicken was dry and the batter lacked flavor (maybe because it was burnt).  

I would go back, but only for the fish and chips.  I do think however that there are better options.
author: Gary A.

description: great fish and chips, u can order from the pud around the corner and get them delivered to the table, use lots of salt
author: Simon W.

description:
Fuck ya I've experienced better...AT OLD CHELSEA!
Ya ya ya, I realize that these two are exactly the same.  When Old Chelsea is closed, they put up a sign that says, "We're open!  At Piccadilly".
So yes, it's almost exactly the same.
But for some reason, the food at Old Chelsea is WAY WAY WAY better, even though they have a lower rating.
- The onion rings are PERFECTLY fried at Old Chelsea; not so much at Piccadilly.
- The old adorable men at Old Chelsea throw in extra FISH; not so much at Piccadilly.
All in all, Old Chelsea is the place for me.  I go there about 4 times a week, and I have no shame in that.
Long live grease!
author: Meh M.

description:
If you ever get a craving for fish and chips- this one's for you :-)
1- star for the mom and pop atmosphere-- i think they need help busing the tables...
2-star cracker crispy batter and moist steamy cod inside 
3-thick cut crunchy french fries
4- Get the combo plate yummy oysters too
Somebody pass the malt vinegar and tabasco please ;-)
Minus the one star for being too close to my yoga place... cuz im always hungry when I get out...
author: Arissa C.

description:
Not bad considering they still don't give you the whole fish...why don't they do that here?!? Seriously, it's the land of gluttony, you would think they would start using the whole fish like they do in the UK instead of "pieces". Anyway, it's pretty damn greasy and tastes good, which gives it the 4 stars right there. The prices are decent -- exactly the same as The Old Chelsea -- but probably the best fish to the chips I've had in San Francisco. 

What else can I say? It's fish and chips done well with loads of vinegar and salt. Yuummmm.
author: Ali L.

description:
Last Friday, after a late night movie at the Lumiere, my friends and I decided to grab a bite to eat on Polk. So we checked out Piccadilly's since it was open and not busy. We grabbed more than a bite. 

Wow, I really love their Oysters, Chicken, and Fish & Chips. No it wasn't all for me, we shared. Aside from the fresh good meat inside, their batter is delicious and I think they deep fry twice for extra crispiness. The elder couple that run the joint were very friendly and accommodating. I don't hang out at Polk St. often, but I'll be back to try their other items. 

Bring your friends, but don't bring your doctor. Oh, and why are there 2 listings for Piccadilly's?
author: Leroid D.

description:
While I would love to give this place 3.5 stars I can't round up to four stars.  See, once upon a time, I was given the ultimate luxury of living within walking distance of the BEST fish n' chips I've EVER had.  I mean the kind wrapped in newspaper, tangy with vinegar and salt and hot and fishy and deliciously chippy.  Nothing will ever compare and goddamn the closing of Lou's in Martinez.  
That being said, I thought that the fish n' chips served up here were okay.  I was freezing, I wanted something filling before hitting the gym and I didn't want to spend a lot of money.  An order of 2 piece fish and chips plus a bottled water came to $7.40.  I had to wait a bit for the food but that means that it wasn't sitting around either.  Only one person working but she was sweet and it was nice and quiet for me and my fried goodness.  Best of all, I have a nice base for tonight's drinking!
author: Jill D.

description:
It is in my 'hood and it hits the spot when I need a late-night, greasy food fix.  It does take awhile to get your order though, or maybe it feels that way when it is the last stop on the TL Drink Train.  

I will not comment on the taste because I have never had the fish and chips when I haven't had a few drinks beforehand so my judgement could be off.  Besides, I drench my order in a gallon of vinegar anyway (East Coast Bay City!), so my taste buds are probably pickled.
author: MakeUp M.

description:
Funny, for year's I passed by this place and never really stopped to smell the fish..but I'm glad that I did. From my understanding this restaurant has been here for ages..They have a "Yelp" decal on the window..sweet. So here it is. 
Any case I give them 4 star's. Fast, hot, and tasty food. The two ladies that run the counter are quiet but they do smile a lot. It's better than talking too much rite? 
The place is not fancy, just good , decent food. 
No crowd when I went there so there is room to sit or even take it to go. 
Ca$h only folks!
author: Smooth R.

description:
After I had dinner at Cafe Gratitude the other night, I felt good - really good - the next day.  Just so healthy and, like, clean.  So where did I have dinner the following night?  Well, the obvious follow-up: Picadilly Fish & Chips, of course!  I love fish & chips so I've been wanting to try this place for a while, and had the perfect opportunity after the Yelp event at O'Reilly's.  

I got the 2 piece fish & chips to go - it's not really a cozy place to hang out & linger.  I was totally charmed by how they wrap it up in newspaper.  Hey, just like they do in England! (or at least from what I've seen on movies.  I've really gotta get myself to London someday soon).  By the time I got them home 20 minutes later, they were a tiny bit soggy, but still really good.  

I'll give the food three and a half stars, the atmosphere two and a half, but the people working there were so nice that I'll bump it up to four stars.
author: DD B.

description:
Was in the area and wanted some fried clam.  The people were very friendly.  I would give it a 5, but they only accept cash. 

Food =good
service =good
author: Roger A.

description:
If you're going to clog your arteries with something, this is the stuff that's worthwhile.   Yes, they're open again!!!!!  

They not only have fish and chips, but oysters, chicken, shrimp, zucchini, mushrooms, and a bunch of other deep-fry-able, heart-stopping  munchies.

Their new layout is, well, pretty much the same as their old layout - just with less grease caked on to everything.  Parking is usually decent within a block or two radius, if you want to run in and pick something up.  Be forewarned though, your car will smell scrumptious for a while during your trip home.  

The food is just as good, if not better than before.  Or maybe I just lucked out and got full sized pieces of fish instead of smaller pieces of fish.  That said, I think I'm done with fried food for at least a month or so.

BTW - This is NOT where Edinburgh Castle gets their fish & chips - they get it from Old Chelsea (around the corner from them).
author: T C.

description: Okay this place simply hands down has the best fish and chip in San Francisco. The prices are very good the only down side is this place is small. So small you might walk by and miss it. This place is a hidden gem.
author: Sean V.

description:
These are pretty authentic English style fish and chips.  Greasy and mushy and filling.  Definitely better with booze.  They don't mess around with Tempura batter or fresh fish or whatever silly SF foodie trend people are calling fish and chips.  The fish, like the fish you get at English shops, is frozen.  The oil has probably been there since they had to change it after the place burned down a year ago.  Its ok.  It still tastes real good. 
The Old Chelsea, the chip shop which delivers to the Edinborough Castle, is in the same neighborhood and nearly identical except, one shop has better fish, and the other shop has better chips and I can never remember which is which until I have them in front of me.
author: Flemm F.

description:
Who goes to get fish and chips and doesn't expect a lot of grease?  It's FRIED for gods sake!!  So, don't be surprised if you leave feeling greasy and fat-full.    

The food is every thing you'd expect from a hole-in-the-wall counter run by one guy who is working his butt off.  Based on that, and the price (3 pieces with chips = approx 9 dollars), its not half bad.   The food was hot, it was fried (go figure), comes wrapped in newspaper, and it comes with home made tarter on the side.   

This isn't SF-snob food; there's nothing healthy or "light" about it.  But, based on the number of Brits standing at the counter, and the line of folks out the door, it appears that some people are still okay with that.
author: Val K.

description:
Definitely some of the best fish and chips I have ever had, fried to steaming hot crunchy perfection right when you order it.  The clams are my favorite, and the shrimp is good too!!

The service is great as well, the owner is a sweet man who even gave us a whole bottle of malt vinegar when we ordered $50 worth of food (what? it was for 8 people!).  The newspapers wrapped around the food are a nice touch.  It's kind of a small place if you plan on eating inside, but it's well worth it if you want to gobble up your food right then and there.
author: Nicole z.

description: I really wanted to like this place but all I can say is meh. The batter tasted plain, the fries sucked (soggy, bland and tasted like cardboard) and the homemade tartar sauce was a little too sweet for my liking.
author: Mike A.

description:
Person working was ultra nice. Very very nice.
I probably should've asked for tartar sauce instead of sticking it out with the vinegar. 
The fish was yummy. It is yes of course done fresh. However I'm not too stuck with its pricing.
The chips were not crispy enough, but the taste was good.
Atmosphere is ok, a little quaint area. Not very attractive, but I like it, represents what it serves.
Would go again if pockets were feeling up to it
author: Winè C.

description: Certainly not the best fish and chips I've had, especially being from Toronto where Chippy's spoiled me. Having said that, this joint is quite good for SF - fish and chips joints are few and far between on the left coast, and this place did the trick. Not too expensive, friendly staff, and they had malt vinegar readily available. The fish is definitely frozen, but pretty good quality. Chips weren't fresh cut, but not bad. I'd go back if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Scott J.

description:
fish and chips.  exactly what they are called is exactly what you should order.

sure they do squid, oysters, clams, chicken, mushrooms, onions, and zuchinni.

this place is obviously a fried food joint so expect it to be oily.  i'm sorry no offense to anyone but when you hear fish and chips expect it to be oily no matter what you order.  its deep fried.  you shouldn't expect a dried out fish in batter without oil in it.

okay with that out of the way.  the one thing i love to have with my fish is MY CHIPS.  on the way home which is on mount davidson a long way from here.  I open the fish and chips and eat the fries while i drive.  they are covered in salt and vinegar and its perfect.  i love the lingering taste of a little vinegar and the salt.  i usually hate salt but this is perfect for this place.

i go to only so many places for Rock COD fish n chips and this is one of them.  get the veggies deep fried too.  they taste great.
author: Bing D.

description: Ghetto little hole in wall. Everything tastes good fried right? Wrong...super greasy fries and the fish is nothing special. The two little Korean ladies are super cute though.
author: Debbie C.

description:
I worked in a fish and chip shop for 4 years as a teenager (ahh those days of getting 2 quid an hour! ), so i feel reasonably qualified to comment on this place =)

They've got a proper fryer (from Cardiff apparently!) which is a good start. And I have to say that the chips are pretty authentic and very tasty. Their the correct large size, slightly crispy on the outside, soft on the inside and not too much grease - great with vinegar of course! It's a shame they don't get much traffic as it means they have to fry the chips each time you order rather than real "fast food".

The fish is a let-down though. I've never had good fish and chips in the US and I wonder if it's just because they don't (can't?) use fresh fish. It always seems to be very small pieces of fish that have been frozen. When they are fried, the texture is just completely off, with an unfortunate reconstituted feel. Inedible unfortunately.

With this fish problem, it would be great if they could add some easier staples to the menu like battered sausages and spam fritters. These are tasty, traditional items that anyone can cook.

So 3 stars for the quality chips, not a place to get a meal, rather to grab a bag of chips after a few pints. Oh, love the korean folk music they sometimes play too =)
author: Jeremy H.

description:
I tried them for the first time sometime ago and I was pleasantly surprise. Inexpensive, fried food perfect to start a night where burning calories is inevitable.
********************************
16AUG07
Now I know better!  My favorite Fish & Chips in the city!!!
A little wait, but  the fresh food is totally worth it!
author: Yamil A.

description: Be sure to ask about the cod cups in the white freezer, it'll completely change your experience and your standards!
author: Ben G.

description:
I can still remember the incredibly large single piece of perfectly battered Cod sitting on a golden mountain of lightly salted finger-sized cut chips served on an oval shaped platter measured from finger-tip to elbow. It was like slow motion when my eyes widened larger then dinner plates as I stepped towards quick dining heaven. Joseph Malin got the right thought when he started it in 1860 in London, England.

With that said, you wonder why I put up 2 stars. Well my description was of when I was in England last year, and if I was straight breaded-out I'd take a trip back to the country side of Coventry.

Maybe I shouldn't compare the food from across the globe by the inventors taking years at a time to perfect it, or maybe I should. I did consider that, but i decided to base my rating solely on Piccadilly.

The fish was overly battered for the size of the fish. It came in a few small pieces and was rather bland. It was dry, no flakey moisture here. The chips were frozen from a bag. No personality in the business either, just off white paint on the walls with scattered tables with vineger bottles on them. 1 star for food, location, and vibe, another for the nice lady.
author: riz l.

description: I had the worst meal at this place.  Uncooked batter, cold fish, poorly cooked.  I left the entire plate of food for 2 people, which wasn't cheap.  I would never come back to this place.  You should be closed down.  There are too many other places in San Fran to eat at.  Just thinking about this place makes me ill.
author: Susan B.

description:
I really wanted to love this place.....but alas its not in the cards :(  
First of all I'm Australian and its tradition to eat fish and chips almost weekly. I have lived in San Francisco for almost 10 years and only been here one time before. I had just returned from an amazing Summer trip home and had a craving for some great Fish and chips. From what I remembered it was OK. I had a bad feeling from the moment I tried to order. The elderly gentleman did not speak English. I had to show him my fingers so he understood how many pieces I wanted. When he placed the fish in the oil it didn't even sizzle. I knew with the oil not being hot enough they were going to soak up all the grease :( And they did. Whats worse was there was hardly any fish in the batter! Maybe a couple of bites! While the fish was cooking I wondered when are they going to put the chips on? Another man came to help and took out pre made chips from a warming tray. WHAT? I asked him...so you dont make the chips fresh? I asked him could you make the chips fresh for me? But he didn't speak English either. They looked greasy, soggy and cold. I was already depressed thinking about them. What a disappointment. The bundles of chips were tepid at best. After driving home I then had to re heat them in my toaster over. I will definitely not be visiting here again. Its not rocket science to cook fish and chips. Use hot oil and cook each order fresh and you are sure to get repeat customers. This place could have been a gold mine if they did a better job. The next day I got our deep fryer out of storage and made amazing fish and chips!
author: Melody M.

description: This is a no hype type of restaurant, a definite hole-in-the-wall. The owner is Chinese, so don't expect a British pub. The fish and chips are OK. It has a crispy batter and the fish is flaky. The only thing bad I have to say is that it is extremely oily...especially the onion rings. It feels like drinking a cup of oil every time you bite into the onion rings. The chips were nothing spectacular. Overall, an average experience.
author: Jun W.

description: I had an interview my hubby was driving me to in the city, and we actually ended up parking a block away from this place. We originally read the reviews and wanted to try it before so we decided to just eat there that day since we had already found parking. The place is owned by an Asian older couple who are very nice and polite. It's a small place and the portions are decent. We decided to split an order of fish and chips since we were short on cash to get two orders (BTW, it's a cash only place so make sure to stop at an ATM beforehand.) The fish was battered a little on the heavier side and the tartar sauce tasted like it was mostly mayo than actual tartar. I don't think this was the best fish and chips we had but it was OK, though we still prefer the one at the SF Fish & Company in the ferry building. The prices were not too high either and overall it was just "OK" for me.
author: Petra S.

description:
It's in a seedy part of Frisco... hole in a wall place on Polk... i wasn't expecting much, but maybe enough to hold it's own match to the old skool London Fish N Chips in the city back in the day... they had a walk- up revolving window food dispenser... he-he... 
the owner was super nice: "EAT EAT first then pay later" .. got the cod fillet and chips, the hubs had fish w/ fried mushroom... they need to change their oil more often... i can taste the remnants of all things fried from what may have been two weeks ago... i drenched my meal w/ the malt vinegar and dipped it in their homemade tartar, which was delish... when i asked for it, the owner came w/ a pitcher filled of the cholesterol goodness and plopped it down on the side of my tray... 
i would recommend getting it to go, so much of the oil would be sucked up by the wax and newspaper it's wrapped in... but it's fish and chips and cheap eats... if you want to eat BAD this place is all GOOD... 
I may go back for some more fish and make room for a corn dog...
author: Aga O.

description:
the fish & chips here is pretty good qualty, I would highly recommend Picadilly, not much seating inside but this place is kept nice and clean.
the service is quick too! when you have a craving for some good old fish & chips this is the place to go!

I ordered two piece fish with onion rings and the owner even added some extra fries, they are nice people.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
When I first walked into the restaurant I was a bit worried that the food wasn't going to be that great. The small hole-in-the-wall type  restaurant had a sort of ghetto look to it, however the food was anything but!

The fish was perfectly fried! Crispy on the outside, no uncooked batter and juicy on the inside! 

I can't wait to go back to SF!
author: Erin M.

description:
Mediocre deep fried fish, and chips that might have been in the freezer a bit too long.  Comes neatly wrapped in old newspaper.  Pretty bare bones but all the grease goes well if you've had some alcohol.  Also try it before alcohol; thats what I did the first time I came here, right before the Elite event at O'Reilly's.  

And don't let the name fool you; there are no reminiscences of Old York.   Maybe the fryer is from there?  And the forty something year old Korean ladies who cold pass for twenty something? Go figure....
author: Summit S.

description:
Piccadilly is BACK! 

It may be my imagination, but it was even better than before. I missed this place so much!
author: Darren M.

description:
I guess things have changed a bit... I've eated at this plac on alomost every visit to San Francisco for the last 20 years.  I think the ownership/management may have changed, as there used to be a couple asian ladies (same ones) every previous trip and this time there was a couple asian guys I'd never seen before.

They were nice enough, but the fish wasn't as good.  The pieces seemed smaller and were cooked in the fryer a bit too long... not enough to burn, but got that extra hard at the ends dark crust that's right before burning.

I asked for some tarter sauce and instead of pouring it out of a pitcher inside the refridgerator as had been the past practice, I was give one-(1) very, very small plastic container the wasn't even filled.  It was enough for only one of my 3 pieces. Kinda felt like if I asked for another, I'd be charged for it. Anyways, I ate the middle out of each of my fish pieces (didn't get any chips) and left.

Sad to say... it was not a memorable visit...
author: Gregory S.

description:
Pretty damn good fish and chip without the jet lag. Its an old school restaurant. You can tell by  fryer that's behind the counter and the cash register that doesn't use electricity. There's about half a dozen little tables and I wouldn't consider this a first date restaurant. The fish and chip was awesome! Some say it was greasy but I thought the opposite. C'mon, its fish and chip! The corn dog was pretty good if you can make room for it.

A couple friends from Scotland tried it out and they can vouch for it being fairly authentic.
author: Gilbert D.

description:
My parents are here visiting and Dad wants fish and chips. But I don't want to take him to Pier 39 or the Wharf. Where to go? Hubby quickly punches in "fish and chips" in his iPhone and up pops this place. Cool! 

The verdict? Again another place I have to say just OK. Even with all the malt vinegar and tartar sauce smothering my fish, I still couldn't taste much of anything except the batter.  It is also twelve hours since we ate there and boy my stomach (and my hips and my thighs) are hating me for all the  oil! But as far as fish and chips places go, I would go back again if the craving strikes - or if Dad wants to re-visit this truly San Francisco experience:)
author: Melani A.

description: English fish and Chips? Maybe...but not to my liking! Service was friendly enough, but lots of translation issues. Owner of shop is Asian, and talking to him you realize he doesn't always really hear what you're saying. We ordered 4-piece fish and chips, which we asked to be wrapped in newspaper. Instead served on regular paper basket. Malt vinegar was Californian...c'mon folks, at least the vinegar should be the real English stuff. Fish tasted authentic enough, but batter was heavy and tasted undercooked on inside. Chips tasted like bigger versions of American french fries. Sorry but I like the soggy, English kind drenched in Vinegar and grease. Overall I would say I was disappointed!
author: Tara C.

description:
I was surprised how good the fish and chips were at this place!  It's a small hole in the wall but clean place, and the owners are really friendly.  The fish is surprisingly light and buttery and the batter nice and light and crispy.  The fries/chips are cut chunky fries style.  I would advise extra vinegar with your salt and vinegar.  It's good with the regular amount of vinegar they put in but it's even better if you ask for extra vinegar.  

If you do take out, just remember, all this fried get soft and soggy eventually.  It was still nice and crispy 10, minutes after, likely anything longer than 15-20 minutes will be a less crispy and light tasting fish n chips.  Ps, the fish stays crispy longer than the chips.

I really like this place.  I'll be coming back.  Five stars for what it is. Fish n Chips.
author: Animal K.

description:
I recently moved from New Orleans where surprisingly there are no fish and chips. That's left me craving them for the past couple years with no satisfaction. I stumbled upon the reviews here and figured I'd run out to try it out. A friend came to town to visit and we headed over. 

The experience is great. We took pictures as the lady battered and fried our fish in that huge fryer. The fish was far too greasy for my taste, but the fries...those were amazing. I'll definitely head back for the fries. Maybe I'll stop and grab a burger on the way.
author: Joe R.

description:
I love fish and chips... I mean I really love them. Perhaps I should say I love good,traditional fish and chips, which this was not.

If you are longing for traditional crispy battered fish, I would not suggest coming here. 

The fish and the fries reminded or the stuff you find in the frozen section of the grocery store. I take that back, I love the cod in the blue box from TJ's which is way better than this..

Point for being withing walking distance of work (though I won't go back for the fish or the chips). Point for nice people working there.
author: Karen S.

description:
So simple so good, 
Swimming in Malt Vinegar, 
Wrapped in Daily News.
author: Brian J.

description: I have no idea what these people are talking about but this place is really really good it has the best fish and chips in the world omg!!!!! You need to check this out! no doubt it'll be perfect. I can't wait to come back. :)
author: Alex K.

description: Definitely my favorite fish & chips in the city.  I've tried the fancy places, but I keep running into weird pieces of fish--too hard, too bony, "off" taste.  At Piccadilly, the fish is always consistently good, not too thick, super crispy and greasy just as fish & chips should be.  I don't know about their tartar sauce because I am a malt vinegar person all the way, and at Piccadilly you never have to ask for malt vinegar; it's all over the tables.  Get some Coke to cut the grease.  The workers are friendly and the counter service works.  It's sparse, the neighborhood is spotty, and the place has no character to speak of, but the food is what I'm after.  I'd recommend getting your order to go for two reasons:  first, you get newspaper that way, and second, the place is pretty grungy and I sometimes get grossed out while eating there if I look around too much.
author: Lorelei S.

description:
I found it funny that the woman on the phone asked me when I was going to be there to pick up the fish and chips... but it made sense when I got there... I was five minutes late but they pulled the fish right out of the fryer! 

I loved the way she wrapped it up in newspaper (a very british trademark) 

The fish like others pointed out was a tad bit greasy for my liking... however it was fresh... so that alone gets four stars 

you do have to request tarter sauce... but I'm not a fan of it... she put the salt and vinegar on for me... it was the right amount too... 

my favorite so far
author: Peta C.

description:
Being a true Englishman there are times when I crave a serving of Fish & Chips. When I do, the only place I think of is Piccadilly on Polk Street.
I have been going there to satisfy my craving for more years than I dare to count and always I am totally satisfied.
When I go there, the only thing on my mind is Fish & Chips  - nothing else matters or warrants criticism.
author: Harold G.

description: OMFG.  So good.  Reminds me of Fish and Chips in the UK.  Really good.  Go here.
author: Fiid W.

description:
You know what's great?

Fish & Chips

These are served by sweet little Asian ladies who fry up your fish & chips made to order. You can get 2 pieces of fish and chips for under $7. Ask for tartar sauce if you want it.
author: Karen J.

description:
This little hole in the wall , "mom and pop" restaurant is a nice little place for a quick food filler. The price is cheap, with 2 pieces of fish and chips for $6. The place is all ran by one fridge, and a giant deep fryer. It's a very small little place with about 3  tables and sets of chairs around them. There is a counter area on the side, and a giant fridge with all the drinks for you to grab. The prices aren't bad at all, but boy ol boy is the food greasy. 

They give you the food in a piece of wax paper then wrap it in newspaper, then put it in a brown paper bag to take out. When I opened the bag, it was a grease filled eating, but to my surprise, everything was still VERY crispy. I don't know the procedures behind what they did, but it was delicious. The woman was very nice, and also gave me 3 pieces of fish for the price of 2. With the price and the friendly service, I could oversee the small area. I give a 3 1/2, but with that extra fish, it pushes me to a 4.
author: Copernicus C.

description:
Piccadilly is our absolute favorite fish & chippery in the Bay Area. My wife and I are both Australians, so our taste's will not be the same as Yanks, but similar to Brits. Though I have to say our American friends are very keen on Piccadilly too; we drive from the east bay to SF just for lunch here, and would often go to Leland Tea around the corner afterwards for tea and chocolate chip scones.

The fish & chips here are beautiful and light. Fish is not too greasy, with a crunchy light golden batter. Pieces aren't huge so you have at least 2 with a relatively small serve of chips. The chips are the star of the show. Very thick, moist and just a little crunch.

Fried mushrooms are also a winner here.

The shop is family owned (at least for several decades now). Very very friendly people.

Love it!
author: Benjamin R.

description: I thought "chip" was British for "french fry" but after eating at Piccadilly I think "chip" must be British for "leaden strip of matter, purportedly  potato but tasting of compressed cardboard".  I have never had a heavier, more tasteless french fry in my life.  The fish itself is okay if you eat it there, but who wants to do that?  I love fried fish but it's just so much better if I fry it myself at home.
author: Lauren C.

description: This place is great for what it is, a deep fried food shack. They have greasy made to order food such as chicken, fish, corn dogs and shrimp plus really addictive fries! The fries and fish are splashed with malt vinegar before they are wrapped and everything is tasty. Because it is made to order the service is a tad bit slow. My major complaint is their hours. It blows my mind they don't stay open late night. I can't even fathom the amount of business they lose out on with the Polk Street bar hoppers.
author: jen w.

description:
i walked by a dozen time before i noticed picca,.. thinking it was another vietnamese cafe/sandwich shop. nope it a sweet korean couple cooking up a british fav. this is a no frills, no plates, plastic forks, pay when  you leave ...local eatary. 

i had two pieces of fish with chips for about $6-7. it came in a basket and i ate it with my hand until i finally got up to ask for a fork. The nice old man showed me basket of forks sitting on the counter..hmm optional i guess. my deep fried lunch was definitely greasy, but this isnt a complaint, i dont mind... i expected it to be oily. what i was surprised at was the lack of seasoning... the no frilly part. i expected it to be salted (like all american food..maybe English food  too ) and throat irritating... but it was perfect for my taste... plus great fries!

i sat there listening to a man praising the owners for their delicious oysters/clams (even though the owner admitted it was frozen not fresh.) the couple even let people change their order after they placed it...how NICE! 

at the end of your meal dont'  be a dine-n-ditch jerk. the couple doesnt hand out bills so just walk up to the counter and pay. they're so trusting!
author: Lynn T.

description: If you don't eat anything deep fried, then steer clear of this place...... you won't allow this four star rating to stand. The service has increased dramatically since reopening and they actually clean thier fryers now too! Tasty grea5y seafood. The fries /onion rings are good too, though I wish they had more options to mix/match platters. Coleslaw was aite. I will definately come back.
author: Eugene G.

description: A fish & chips craving came over me one recent Sunday afternoon. I journeyed from Portrero Hill to this area because I recalled a few fish & chips places dotting Polk St. Piccadilly leaped out at me what with its yellow signage and diagonal word placement. Parking was not difficult to find. Inside, it looked to be a popular spot. There was a family and a couple guys already seated and one man waiting for his to go food. I squeezed past them and waited to place my order. It took them a while to bring me the three piece fish and chips; I would have preferred it to come out a lot sooner. After I seated myself, a few others came in and got their food before me. Nonetheless, I was happy with the fish fry. I love me some fish & chips now and then. The End.
author: Evelyn B.

description: So after the rave reviews and Xochitl P. recommending this place, I finally checked it out. Got the three parts fish, one part fries thingie. All good, not too greasy comfort food. My fish tasted kinda neutral, though. I'm not sure whether that's supposed to be, but I recall having fish & chips in England that tasted slightly different. Will have to do a repeat visit to find out the truth. Because it's out there.
author: Roland A.

description:
This is a great place for fish and chips if you like to eat deep fried globs of flour and frozen bits of what may have once been fish. 

I think it's the worst meal I've ever eaten in SF. But if I don't get sick tonight I'll promise not to tell anybody how below-average it was and we'll call it even. 

Naaah. Better spread the word.
author: richard l.

description: I like this place for the once every two or three month Fish & Chips Craving, lets face it if deep fried food was not bad for you i would eat here more often.  their combo plate is great 10 bucks and you get plenty of variety.  The Owners are very nice people.  Their Shrimp & clams are so GOOD!
author: Eric G.

description: How come only obscenely nice, cool, and funny people work at fish and chips places? Anyway, these guys rock. Go to Hemlock and get yer grub on at Piccadilly. There's nothin' better to sop up that delicious beer than fluffy fish.
author: Blake E.

description: Really good fish and chips.  Not the best atmosphere - truth be told, the place is kind of skank - but I haven't found better fish and chips in SF thus far.  The owners are really nice and definitely give some hands-on service.  The food is prepped to order so there is some waiting involved but nothing over the top.  I will definitely be back, for the food not the atmosphere.
author: prior O.

description:
um yeah...where's the fish

this place was disgusting. 

should have eaten at chai-yo across the street

maybe then i wouldn't have felt the need to follow up my meal with a hot shower.

heavy greasy poorly fried ickyness

onion rings weren't bad

and the restroom was something out of a gritty drama involving street kids and methamphetamines
author: Alex P.

description: It is what it is. Well done Fish & chips, reasonable price. It's not a lot of things, but it is a decent lunch and I'll be going back the next time I'm in the mood for it. My girlfriend had the battered shrimp which was good as well. I was most impressed by the fries. I generally don't like thick-cut fries b/c they never seem to be cooked well, but amazingly these were. Crispy outside, cooked through, and barely greasy. It's fish and chips and a no frills place so it's hard to say much more about it, more than I'll be heading back before too long for more.
author: Ross M.

description: This is one of the last true fish and chips joints in San Francisco.  With it being one of the only options I'd have to say it's pretty good.  Fries are nice and thick.  You also have a choice of onion rings which they batter themselves.  The shrimp is pretty good and so is the squid.  They serve your order on sheet of waxed paper then wrapped in newspaper.  The Korean couple that runs the place is really nice.  Food is cooked to order and there's a good amount of seating.  Parking maybe rough at times and the neighborhood isn't that great.  Cash only so come prepared.
author: Terrence L.

description: This is the real deal, if somewhat bare-bones. Some of the best chips in the city. A little more upscale but pretty damn good too is Taylor's Refresher in the Ferry Building.
author: Nish N.

description: If you want fish n chips, but don't wanna have to cross the pond for the real deal... Piccadilly Fish & Chips is the place to go.  Recommended by my buddy from the UK, the first time there, this Irish dude came in placed a humongo order, and couldn't stop raving about the authenticity.  Having  been there a few times now, I can totally attest to the food and its quality.  Also the folks that own the place and really sweet people and always happy to see you ;)  No hesitation on my part to recommend this family owned business.
author: Vivek N.

description:
i FINALLY gave this place a try last saturday. i was craving something good and hearty to eat while i watched the montreal canadiens hockey game (fuck yeah, i subscribe to the NHL center ice package!). so i got the 3-piece fish and chips combo. 

overall, i thought the fish and chips were good and it passed my test - as far as fish and chips go, BUT i do have a couple of small complaints:

1) the cook was having a coughing fit while she was cooking my food ... although, she turned her head as she was couhing, it was still rather troubling for me to see her hacking up a lung while she was in the midst of preparing my food.

2) the grease had this sort of donut taste to it. so my fish kinda tasted like a donut. maybe they use a sweeter oil? who knows.

i like their fish and chips better than most places in the city, so i'll probably return here when i have the craving.
author: James J.

description: So greasy, but soooo good! I'm so glad to hear that this place has reopened its doors. My only complaint is that they don't give you nearly enough napkins and the tables were always a bit sticky. Nevertheless, I know I'll be dropping by sometime in the near future...armed with a roll of paper towels and wearing stretchy waistband pants!
author: Nathalie L.

description: I might rate the fish and chips at Wilde Oscar's better but this kicks the Old Chelsea/Edinburgh Castle connection to the curb.
author: patrick g.

description: I hate to give anyone just 1 star, but, I must say... yikes!  The fish was nasty and the fries were just ok.  No ranch?  I ate 2 bites of the fish and tossed it.  AND I LOVE FISH AND CHIPS!!!  At least the soda was good.
author: Noneya B.

description: Yum. Traditional fish and chips. Don't be deterred by the ambiance and general decor. They more than make up for it with the fried oysters.
author: Stefanie L.

description: About as authentic as you can get...or so I hear...except for the fact that in Ireland, they don't even use the piece of filmy white paper - just the newspaper!!  These fried goodies taste great going down, but if you've got a weak stomach, watch out.  These puppies are double dipped in at vat of hot greese!
author: Sarah S.

description: I have literally been going to Piccadilly for years - I think its the same two little Asian ladies that defy the aging process still working there. Usually some pretty interesting entertainment from the passersby, too.
author: Robert M.

description: These Korean Ladies Keep it real, good service and good Fish and Chips.
author: erik e.

description: This is where Edinburgh Castle gets the fish & chips. It's some of the best in town. Yum!
author: Colleen B.

description: If you are in the mood for fish and chips, it doesn't get much better than this. The atmosphere kind of blows, but the service is friendly. And the fries - the fries!!! - they are some of the yummiest I've had. Crispy on the outside, but the inside has this mashed-potatoe consistency that is just glorious. MMM. But don't even think about putting ketchup on anything here. That malt vinegar is as essential to the fish and the chips as mustard is to a hot dog.
author: Sahra H.

description: I've been going here for 2 or 3 years now and i love it every time    Crispy on the outside and Moist on the inside.  2 pc with fryes 6.50ish.  Soda extra.  I wish they had reqular tap water instead of having to buy bottle water.   The owners are great, sweet couple.   I always try to sit next to the window and watch all the women walk by from the yoga studio...   One time I asked for some tartar sauce and ketchup.  She came out and scooped it out of a big tupperware.  I would of like to have a bar with condiments so I wouldnt have to bother to ask for another scoop.. Other than that  excellent seating, food and quick service.
author: Simon L.

description: Ghetto place? Yes.  Run by two Koreans serving up English style fish & chips? Questionable. (Unless owners have changed.) But the end result is some really good and well done fish & chips.   I go home happy after eating there.
author: Chris C.

description:
Definitely not the best fish and chips that I've eaten.  In fact, I prefer the fish and chips at The Pig and Whistle on Geary or at the Wooden Nickel in Watsonville.

The real problem, I believe, is the oil.  It seems to be of poor quality and leaves a very oily aftertaste.  I liked the batter and the taste of the fish, I just didn't like the taste of the oil.  I ordered my fish with onion rings, which were OK--freshly battered, not a real crisp batter, but a soft barely crispy batter.  Again, the taste of the oil spoiled any good impression I had.

I'll try Old Chelsea next time.
author: Richard C.

description:
deeeelicious fish and chips. perfect texture and taste, made even better with vinegar and same salt (as already noted).

the nicest cutest old korean lady behind the counter will total your bill on a huge calculator and show you the total. and if you order to go, it will be wrapped in newspaper, just like ye olde country.
author: Lisa M.

description:
not bad.  if you're hungering for fish and chips, this is your place.

its definitely made fresh.  you see the guy dip the fish into the batter and throw it into the vat of wondrously hot oil.  same with the fries.  not the cleanest place, not in the best area, but then again, most fish n chips joints aren't in good areas - similar to good fried chicken (applies to most chicken places except for honey kettle's in LA).  the older man who was cooking was really nice, and very friendly.

definitely the joint for fish n chips and probably most things fried, obviously not much else.
author: Jason J.

description: Been going to this place for over 20 years,but I had not been in a long time. It was still just as good! Crispy, a little greasy, lots of malt vinegar!! Great thick chips
author: ruby b.

description:
i love this place, its a great fish & chips place in the city.  they also own another place several blocks away in between polk & larkin Old Chelsea.  the fish & chips here rock.  the fish is always golden & crispy, not too cakey, tender & flaky on the inside, the fries are thick.  best eaten with tons of malt vinegar & a touch of salt.  

if you are undecided or wishing for some variety you can always order the combo plate which has oysters, shrimp, fish & chips.  either way you go you will not be disappointed, their food is good & you leave full.  

take out is available, they wrap their stuff up in newspaper just like in europe to seal in the flavors.  be forewarned, if you get take out your car will smell like delicious fish & chips for abit.  

picadilly on polk returned from the ashes after sustaining a fire.  the sister store old chelsea is currently under rennovation but only opens after 4pm.  the decor in the picadilly is simple standard fare & the decor in the old chelsea is a bit retro & sterile, old funky 70's floral designed chairs & white washed walls.  

they only take cash so make sure you hit the atm before going.  
street parking is not too bad at either location.  if you are in the area craving fried food you need to try this little gem.
author: larry s.

description: This place is nasty now.  It use to be good.  This is the last time i'll be visiting this place.  The oil was old and probably should of been changed.  The fish got smaller and still looked huge thanks to all the batter used.  If you like greasy tasting food cooked in old oil.  This is the place for you.
author: KandM L.

description: I eat here at least once every couple of weeks...the people who work here are always nice and courteous. I always get the 3 piece with chips and onion rings...and add cole slaw...there's other things to order like oysters,crab and prawns...they also have chicken,which is out of place and i don't really know if they cook it in the same oil as the fish...but the main thing is the fish and chips...add some salt and malt vinegar and you have a very filling meal...no beer,only soda and juices
author: David W.

description: Authentic Australian-style fish&chips.  The best I've tasted in the U.S.  The chips are nice and thick, and remind me just of the type of chips I used to get from the local fish&chip shops back home.
author: Juliet R.

description: Hands down the yummiest fish and chips with a ton of salt and vinegar place. The people who makes these goodies are always nice and place is kept pretty clean.
author: Diane M.

description: Great Fish & Chips, and fried chicken too. Friendly service at great prices. If you love excellent and greasy Fish & Chips, go to Piccadilly. Don't forget to ask for the tartar sauce.
author: Ronnie Ray H.

description:
My friend both got sick within hours after eating here... the ladies were very nice and the serving size was good, but definitely not worth the intestinal agony.  

Also, you have to request tartar sauce or they won't volunteer it.
author: Robb M.

description: The place does one thing. It fries the shit outta stuff. I don't know who was expecting a gourmet meal here. The fries are the bomb, the fish a tad greasy and they WRAP IT IN A NEWSPAPER. Don't go for the locale, the ambiance or the luxurious seating. Go for old fashioned battered and fried cod and thick, crispy steak fries. If you are feeling lavish try the scallops(add salt).
author: Christopher V.

description: two thumbs down for the poor batter and crappy french fries!!!! there's way, way, way better places to get your fish and chips and i've been to three establishment that this place won't measure up at all.
author: Nelle A.

description: Surprisingly good fish & chips.  The older guy that owns it is awesome. He often gives you 3 pieces of fish when you order 2! You can't argue with that. Cheap and cheerful.
author: Gazza B.

description: After reading the reviews below, I had to check to make sure I had the right place.  How anyone could give this place more than two stars is inexplicable to me.  The fish was nasty -- it was chewy and still cold in spots.  The batter was greasy.  And the best part of all: when I asked for a fork, I was shown a try of recycled plastic forks on the counter, which had supposedly been washed but there were chunks of food on at least one of them.  I almost called the Board of Health.  Avoid this place at all costs.  Seriously.
author: william e.

description: After spending some time at S.N.O.B., my friend and I decided it was a little late to run over to Pacific Fresh.  Luckily a brief look out the storefront I noticed Piccadilly across the way.  since I'd heard this was a good place for Fish & Chips, and we were thinking of having that anyways, it was the perfect opportune to try it out.  Now I don't know what it looked like before the burned down, but it really wasn't an eyecatcher.  It seemed pretty bare, except for the giant fryers behind the counter.  While the menu seemed very lengthy with various seafood options, we settled on a 5-piece fish and chips meal with a side of onion rings.  Someone wasn't kidding about the grease.  While it was tasty, I definitely felt like a few zits were ready to form.  I'm pretty sure it was grease oozing out of the fish and onion rings.  A little too much for me....grease that is.  I prefer H.Salt Esq. Fish & Chips, where it's not as greasy IMO.
author: JeFF T.

description: I'm sure my other review explained it all.  Basically, this was the best fish and chips place out there in the city, but now I'm not sure how I feel about it.  I came by today with my father (like old times) and to our surprise, there was an unfamiliar face working behind the counter.  But this couldn't be.  I mean, the Piccadilly I knew had an elderly Korean couple working there, the sweetest people who enjoyed what they did at the shop.  We'd walk in, and we would always be greeted by the couple with warm smiles on their faces.  My favorite item on the menu?  Oyster and chips...with lots of malt vinegar...and a root beer on the side.  But then I realized that the outside of the shop did look a bit updated, the menu had slight changes (which showed that they no longer serve/cook deep fried squid), the root beer bottles in the fridge were replaced by canned soda, and the old cash register that never worked (but made a cute prop) was gone.  While I was waiting for my order, a sweet older woman came by and asked the man, "Do you remember me?  I always sit over there (pointing towards the window seating area). And I always order the squid and the chips."  Now you see, the original owners would most of the time remember their customers. The old man was confused, and barely spoke english.  I felt bad on both ends.  Even when I got my order, the size was much smaller.  The oysters were tiny, but still really tasty.  And some of the chips didn't taste fully cooked.  Despite my slight disappointment in my visit/order today, I still think Piccadilly is the best out there.  And I'm really going to miss that sweet old couple who made my visits quite special.  I only hope for the best for the new Piccadilly!
author: Jasmine T.

description: Ran into this Piccadilly Fish & chips randomly a saturday afternoon... and it was one great day. I am a big fan of fish and chips, not just any fish & chips, but the tranditional fish & chips. Lived in london for a little while and got addicted ever since. Haven't been able to find any thing even close in the state. Then when I walked in Piccadilly, I knew I was in luck. vingear and salt on every table... thick-cut chips and fish were cooked to order. Fish was juicy and tender, chips were fresh and flavorful. I can't wait to go back!!
author: MM G.

description: This is my favorite fish n chips in the city.  They are soooo good, don't expect any frills though.
author: Michael F.

description: the sweet old Korean couple makes my order fresh and tasty, it just reminded me of New Zealand ... .. .
author: Flora H.

description: if you ever have cravings for fried foods, they fry just about everything here. yay malt vinegar!
author: Lijia X.

description: Pretty simple -- fish and chips or fish and onion rings. I'm not a big fan of fish and chips but I thought I would give this place a try. It might be good if you are into ye olde fish and chips but I don't think I will be visiting this place again.
author: Salil A.

description:
for sure this is not the best fish & chips in existence, but i have a weakness for this place for several reasons. 
* extremely nice folks running the place
* kickass vintage fish fryer 
* they always seem to hook you up with more than you ordered
* very unpretentious & centrally located
author: Galen R.

description: love this place. been going here since i was a young buck.
author: Avery H.

description: Came in once a long time ago.  Got a large piece of fried batter that had eaten a tiny piece of fish.  Cut it open to eat the fish and left the body of batter.  Tasted like old, brown, frying oil.
author: e g.

description: good place, salty, vinegar with the right sweet and salt. and ok owners./
author: Leigh McInnis Lee G.

description: Piccadilly Fish & Chips has ruined me insofar as the fish and chips are so good I will accept no substitute (even though I have subsequently tried the fish and chips at other restaurants numbering in the double digits). The experience starts with the location, in the night life hub of Polk Gulch (don't accept the euphemistic other name that is used for that area!). After playing a live punk show in the nearby Kimo's bar, nothing is more satisfying then walking into Piccadilly later in the evening and smelling the aroma of delicious oil in the air, and viewing the spectacular sight of the imported (and aesthetically pleasing) English deep fryers. The star of the show is the fresh cod and potatoes used for the fish and chips, and this is what I would recommend one to order. The price is fantastic for the quality, and the rapidity of the cuisine creation is delightful. The fish and chips come finely wrapped in the newsprint of that week. The savory odor of the oil, breading, and fish is further drawn out when the vinegar is applied to the ensemble. The wonderful vinegar smell flies upward to the nose, causing a Pavlovian generation of saliva and awakening the taste buds for the pleasure that is about to ensue. The fish itself absolutely does not taste fishy, which is the first major reason that I find these fish and chips superior. The second is the quality and taste of the breading (who's ingredients and method of preparation remain a mystery to me). The potatoes are just of the right thickness and flavor to counterbalance the lightness and intransigence of the fish. My ideal accompaniment to the meal is a chilled can of Diet Coke, and for me the best way to enjoy any freshly deep fried food is when it is so hot that it must be washed down with cool liquids of some kind to avoid burning the mouth and tongue. The memory of the taste of the fish and smell of the aroma of the oils will haunt you for hours after leaving, reminding you of the multitude of delights that you just experienced.
author: Benjamin V.
